title: Turnaround : I finnally understand why riot made games shorter
body:
Well it's kinda weird but with some research here is something i forgot and many of us 

Well it seems that we all forgot that Asians play in communities in internet cafés and pc banks aren't free. The open mid phenoma doesn't really exists in na or eu. But in asia they really let the opponents go straight to the nexus if the game is looking bad to win time and to not spend a lot of money. In asia lol is really popular so after school or college you go with 4 friends play games in internet cafe its easier for you than everyone at home. And many kids don't have their own computer.

So winning time for them is winning money. It's a little bit paradoxal to have to pay to play a free game. Kids or young people don't always have a lot of money... yep... we don't live all in wealthy countries (china for example).

Riot said they used surveys in the past and majority of the players wanted shorter games. Majority of the players = china and korea. That why we don't hear their complains.

I foud this video which talks about the subject https://youtu.be/UjunINOwvVw

After knowing this, well i have to admit i'm not against it, if it can help them.

However i think its a problem that the entire world has to adapt to this phenomena. Because in na or eu it this phenomena doesn't really exists

I think riot should have a kinda different meta for occidental countries and asian countries. Or try to find another solution.

Your forgetting that Riot doesn't care about us. The asian gaming cafe demands games under 30 minutes. And the asian gaming cafe is Tencents primary market. A few years ago tencent reported that one single demographic (asian gaming cafe) was reported for over 25% of their annual revenue. One demographic, for one single game (tencent has like a dozen), makes over 25% of their profits... That is HUUUUUGE. And I can only imagine that it has grown since then with all the game mechanics changes that Riot has implemented that cater to them.

And that aside Asian players outnumber us like 4 to 1 or some absurd number, so even by voting with our wallets and or boycotting will not even be noticed.

Plus changes that make the LCS casters scream louder over BIG PLAYS, and the LCS just franchised into a billion dollar industry. This is on top of and aside from it's billion dollar earnings from previous years.

Maybe I'm just getting old but I've always appreciated sustained fighting mechanics, (resource management, tower pressure, chaining cooldowns, chases, etc.) to the big wombo plays that are mostly game enders. Yay I did good! My reward? Game is over and I get a gold star. No, I'd rather be rewarded with more items and have the ability to roam the map harder and exert more pressure for another 20 minutes.

Unfortunately I think that is just our problem. *We* are getting old and remember when gaming served a purpose other than just an ego boost for scoring KDA.

Sometimes I forget that even though I fell in love with the game (and other games, Pre-WotLK WoW etc) for the complexity and depth of strategy, it's still a children's game. Or rather has become a children's game, and despite my personal sentiments, being a children's game perhaps isn't the worst thing in the world. Better to have loved and lost and that sort of thing.

making games shorter is one thing but this is getting insane the game is decided in the first 4 minutes 80% of the games nowadays if the jg ganks bot at around lvl 6 by the time bot lane revives and gets into their lane chances are they are missing 2 towers already. they are just playing with us at this point trying to see how long we can stand those absurd changes. they must understand that we pay their bills.
We don't pay their bills, that is the point. We are insignificant to their numbers and profits, as well as easily replaceable by larger demographics.

Dude Tencent released a statement that just one single demographic (the asian gaming/internet cafe market) makes over 25% of their annual revenue, alone. Just that one single market, for a single game (they have like a dozen games) makes over a quarter of their total revenue... That is HUUUGE. And that was a few years ago, I can only imagine they have grown since then. 

And then your talking about GDP depicting who spends more? They are already paying to play the game, a free game and they pay to play it at a rate of like 2.3:1.. And they shell out for much more than skins, they buy boosts which I didn't think anyone was foolish enough to buy. 

in 2015 Riot released a statement saying that 15% of Korea's TOTAL POPULATION plays League... That's roughly 30 million people in Korea alone...

2017 Riot's server population puts NA at 10% of League's playerbase (EUW comes in #1 btw), TEN PERCENT compared to Korea at 23.5%... This also shows that the previous two years Korea came in #1 both times.

Again your talking of GDP, when that is just a gross estimation of a national economy. It's not at all an accurate indication of a single company in a single industries standings. 

And your still talking hypothetically. This "shunning" (bad word choice again, but we will run with it) has already taken place. The asian gaming cafe market demands games not run longer than 30 minutes. Around season 5 Riot started implementing snowball mechanics, and other mechanics and meta's that put focus on early game and snowballing. There are currently around a dozen or so snowball mechanics, all intentionally designed to speed up the game progression rate, and shorten the length of game time.

But lets get to the juicy part:
In 2017 Asian gaming industry revenue was around 51.2b... and NA? HALF THAT at 27.5b... 

>etc etc asain countries dont even come close to touching our per capita gdp. Not even 1/5 for china.

Btw China is/has been the world leader in the gaming industry revenue for many years now. (close to a decade?)
